summary: The appellant was charged with conspiracy and armed robbery at the High Court of Osun State. The prosecution alleged that on December 21, 1999, the appellant and others robbed Alhaja Sariyu at gunpoint, stealing N140,000 and bank documents. The appellant claimed he was merely a commercial motorcyclist who had transported someone to the scene. He was convicted and sentenced to death by the trial court, which was affirmed by the Court of Appeal. The Supreme Court found that the prosecution failed to prove the case beyond reasonable doubt, noting problems with the appellant's confession (Exhibit Q) and lack of corroborating evidence. The court also noted that a key suspect identified as having a gun was released without explanation. The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, setting aside the lower courts' decisions and acquitting the appellant.
outcome: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the judgments of both lower courts, and discharged and acquitted the appellant of the charges of conspiracy to commit armed robbery and armed robbery.
ratios: When a statement (like Exhibit Q) is excluded from evidence, as it should be, and there is insufficient evidence left on record which could have sustained the verdict of guilt returned by the trial court, the inevitable conclusion is that the guilt of the appellant was not established.
Where there are doubts as to the guilt of an accused person, such doubts must be resolved in favor of the accused.

Where prosecution's evidence is found to be contradictory on a material issue, the court should give the benefit of that doubt to an accused person that stems from the non-credibility of such evidence and discharge and acquit him.

precedents.name: State v. Salawu (2011) All FWLR (Pt. 594) 35
precedents.context: That was the decision of this court in State v. Salawu (2011) All FWLR (Pt. 594) 35, (2011) LPELR - 82, (2011) 18 NWLR (Pt. 1279) 580 at page 605, paragraphs C-F.

precedents.name: Nsofor v. State (2004) Vol. 20 NSCQR 74
precedents.context: On the manner of taking the statement of the accused person by the police, counsel cited the case of Nsofor v. State (2004) Vol. 20 NSCQR 74, (2004) 18 NWLR (Pt. 905) 292 at pages 314-315, (2005) All FWLR (Pt. 242) 397, and submitted that the process of recording such statement does not allow the accused person to be subjected to all sorts of inhuman treatment by the law enforcement officers in order to obtain accused's statement.

precedents.name: Oforlete v. State (2000) FWLR (Pt. 12) 2081
precedents.context: In the case of Oforlete v. State (2000) FWLR (Pt. 12) 2081, (2000) 12 NWLR (Pt. 681) 415 at 436, (2000) 7 SCNJ 162, (2000) 7 WRN 80 at 106, (2000) 7 SC (Pt. 1) 80. Achike JSC., (as he then was) observed that, doubt (referring to doubt as to the possibility of the appellant committing the offence) must be resolved in favour of the appellant where the allegation of his offence has not been proved beyond reasonable doubt.

precedents.name: Chukwu v. State (1996) 7 NWLR (Pt. 463) 686
precedents.context: This court per Wali JSC, (as he then was) held in the case of Chukwu v. State (1996) LPELR (856) 1, (1996) 7 NWLR (Pt. 463) 686 at 701, paragraphs G-H as follows: 'Where prosecutions evidence is found to be contradictory on a material issue, the court should give the benefit of that doubt to an accused person that stems from the non-credibility of such evidence and discharge and acquit him.'

precedents.name: Ahmed v. State (1999) 7 NWLR (Pt. 612) 641
precedents.context: In criminal cases, any doubt, as to the guilt of the accused arising from the contradictions in the prosecution's evidence of vital issues must be resolved to the benefit of the accused. See Ahmed v. State (1999) 7 NWLR (Pt. 612) 641 at 673, (1999) 5 SC (Pt. II) 39, (2001) FWLR (Pt. 34) 438.

precedents.name: Ikwunne v. State (2000) 5 NWLR (Pt. 658) 550
precedents.context: In the case of Ikwunne v. State (2000) 5 NWLR (Pt. 658) 550 at page 561, (of a persuasive authority), Niki Tobi (JCA) (as he then was) held and said: 'In a charge of conspiracy, the prosecution has the burden to prove not only the inchoate or rudimentary nature of the offence but also the meeting of the minds of the accused persons with a common intention and purpose to commit a particular offence.'
